Test case:

1. After installing CDT, the Problems view is on top by default.  Without
changing this ordering, create a managed project, call it MgdCpp (for example)
2. Add a file to MgdCpp, call it main.cpp - this will kick off a build that
never finishes (because auto-build is enabled by default).
3. Close Eclipse.

Result: You are hung and must use the Windows Task Manager to force quit.

4. Restart Eclipse.

Result: Eclipse restarts, but note the progress bar in the botton right corner -
this should not be present.

5. Close Eclipse again.

Result: You are hung ....  again, and must use the Windows Task Manager to force
quit ... again.

6. Restart Eclipse one more time and you will get an error message pointing you
to a log file in the configuration directory that will contain something that

I see a similar problem now using the latest from CVS.  I was investigating 
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=53620 which has a particular piece 
of source from Linux kernal (or tests, I'm not sure).  Was this defect fixed for 
our M8 (and just not marked as RESOLVED) or does anyone else still see the 
problem.

My steps to reproduce it:
1. Create new Managed Make (C) project.
2. Import fw-emu.c.  (Will be attached shortly).
3. Autobuild should kick in (without setting up include paths, you'll get 
compile errors).
4. While build is going on, attempt to dirty the editor buffer.  (i.e. type in 
CEditor)
5. DEADLOCK

After killing it and starting Eclipse back up, there are errors opening editors 
and seeing the C++ Projects View.  It takes a couple of restarts/refreshes/Reset 
Perspectives to get things going again.

I am running on SuSE Linux 9.0, Eclipse M8 for GTK, w/Sun's JDK 1.4.2.  I have 
attached the different stack traces of all the threads that were blocking 
suspicously, but my take on it is that CMarkerAnnotationModel (which is an 
IResourceChangeListener) is doing tons of work, including notifying other 
listeners of annotation changes, and one of these listeners is creating SWT 
Images for the label provider.  We need to restructure our MarkerAnnotationModel 
to use runnables or work-queues.

Created an attachment (id=9343)
Linux source

This source file, imported into a ManagedMake C Project on Linux will cause
tons of compile errors.

The original problem was fixed for M8 and just not marked as resolved from the 
looks of it ;)

I tried to reproduce the problem you mentioned on both Windows XP and SLES 9.

Windows XP:
The UI locked up when I typed in the CEditor, though if I left it long enough - 
it would come back and appear to complete the failed build.  When I exited from 
my Eclipse session, I was prompted with the "blocking" dialog telling me that I 
could not exit until the build was complete (which was the case according to 
the console view prior to exiting) - though after a finite amount of time, 
Eclipse did close down.  So something is certainly wonky here.  There were no 
errors reported to the .log file.

SLES 9:
I experience the deadlock you described.  I waited 10 minutes and the UI never 
came back.  There were no errors reported to the .log file.

So I guess my problem that I have witnessed this morning is the same as John's.

I will duplicate my critical bug that I have logged this morning to this one.  
(Can't delete a line of code when a large file is opened in the editor).The 
build mechanism was running in the background.
*** Bug 58134 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

This defect was originally raised because IProblem markers were preventing 
managed make from completing a build. This has been fixed and as a result is 
no longer blocking - hence I am closing this bug...and opening a new one for 
the other problem stated below.

However, there is another problem here - which appears on Linux but apparently 
not Windows. If you have a file that has many build errors (such as the one 
provided by John), it takes an amazingly long time to get the error output. In 
fact if you type something in the CEditor while the project is building it 
freezes up the editor.  (This problem has to do with the 
CEditorErrorTickUpdater taking a long time to refresh). BTW, it is not 
deadlocked as it eventually comes around but it does take a very long time to 
get all the errors.

This bug has been verified on Eclipse build 20040611 and CDT build 
200406110301, and it passes.

Pixy.
